p: Analysis of survival during a year since the beginning of the breeding season revealed that the control males survived better than the warm‐treated individuals (Cox proportional hazard model including family as a random effect: β ± SE = 0.246 ± 0.157, χ 2 1 = 3.89, p = .049). The survival curves suggested that this difference was mainly due to higher mortality rates of the warm‐treated males during the early breeding season and postbreeding season (Figure 1c).
